questions.question: Change the following direct speech to indirect speech: She said, 'I am reading a book.'
options: She said that she was reading a book.
She said that she is reading a book.
She says that she was reading a book.
questions.explanation: In indirect speech, the present continuous tense 'am reading' changes to the past continuous 'was reading' because the reporting verb 'said' is in the past tense.

questions.question: Convert this indirect speech to direct speech: He said that he had finished his homework.
options: He said, 'I have finished my homework.'
He said, 'I had finished my homework.'
He said, 'I finished my homework.'
questions.explanation: In direct speech, the past perfect 'had finished' changes to present perfect 'have finished' to reflect the original tense spoken.

questions.question: Identify whether this sentence is direct or indirect speech: 'I will go to school,' said Priya.
options: Direct speech
Indirect speech
Neither
questions.explanation: This is direct speech because it uses quotation marks to show Priya's exact words.

questions.question: Choose the correct indirect speech for: 'Please sit down,' said the teacher.
options: The teacher asked to sit down.
The teacher said to sit down.
The teacher requested to sit down.
questions.explanation: For polite commands like 'please sit down,' indirect speech often uses 'asked' followed by 'to' and the verb.

questions.question: What is the indirect speech of: 'I like to play football,' said Rohan.
options: Rohan said that he liked to play football.
Rohan said that he likes to play football.
Rohan says that he liked to play football.
questions.explanation: The present simple 'like' changes to past simple 'liked' in indirect speech when the reporting verb is in the past.

questions.question: Convert to indirect speech: 'Are you coming to the party?' asked Neha.
options: Neha asked if I was coming to the party.
Neha asked are you coming to the party.
Neha asked if I am coming to the party.
questions.explanation: Questions in indirect speech use 'if' or 'whether,' and the present tense 'are coming' shifts to past 'was coming.'

questions.question: Which is the correct indirect speech for: 'I can dance well,' said Anjali.
options: Anjali said that she can dance well.
Anjali said that she could dance well.
Anjali said that she dances well.
questions.explanation: The modal verb 'can' changes to 'could' in indirect speech when reported in the past.

questions.question: Change to direct speech: The girl said that she was singing a song.
options: The girl said, 'I am singing a song.'
The girl said, 'I was singing a song.'
The girl said, 'I sing a song.'
questions.explanation: The past continuous 'was singing' in indirect speech changes to present continuous 'am singing' in direct speech.

questions.question: Fill in the blank with the correct word: He said, 'I ___ hungry.' (am / was)
options: am
was
Both are correct
questions.explanation: In direct speech, 'am' is used because it reflects the speaker's current state at the time of speaking.

questions.question: Correct the error in this indirect speech: She said that she will go to the market.
options: She said that she would go to the market.
She said that she will go tomorrow.
She said that she went to the market.
questions.explanation: In indirect speech, 'will' changes to 'would' because the reporting verb 'said' is in the past tense.

questions.question: What is the indirect speech of: 'I have lost my pen,' said the boy.
options: The boy said that he has lost his pen.
The boy said that he had lost his pen.
The boy said that he lost his pen.
questions.explanation: The present perfect 'have lost' changes to past perfect 'had lost' in indirect speech.

questions.question: Choose the correct direct speech for: My father told me that he was busy.
options: My father said, 'I am busy.'
My father said, 'I was busy.'
My father said, 'I will be busy.'
questions.explanation: The past tense 'was busy' in indirect speech changes to present tense 'am busy' in direct speech.

questions.question: Identify the type of speech: The principal ordered the students to line up.
options: Direct speech
Indirect speech
Both
questions.explanation: This is indirect speech because it reports the principal's command without quoting the exact words.

questions.question: Convert to indirect speech: 'Don’t run in the corridor!' shouted the monitor.
options: The monitor shouted not to run in the corridor.
The monitor shouted to don’t run in the corridor.
The monitor shouted run not in the corridor.
questions.explanation: Negative commands in indirect speech use 'not to' followed by the base verb.

questions.question: What is the correct indirect speech for: 'I must finish my work,' said Kavita.
options: Kavita said that she must finish her work.
Kavita said that she had to finish her work.
Kavita said that she has to finish her work.
questions.explanation: The modal 'must' changes to 'had to' in indirect speech when reported in the past.

questions.question: Change to direct speech: The coach said that the team would practice later.
options: The coach said, 'The team will practice later.'
The coach said, 'The team would practice later.'
The coach said, 'The team practices later.'
questions.explanation: The future 'would' in indirect speech changes to 'will' in direct speech.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: In indirect speech, 'today' changes to ___.
options: that day
yesterday
tomorrow
questions.explanation: Time expressions like 'today' change to 'that day' in indirect speech to adjust the time reference.

questions.question: Which sentence is in indirect speech?
options: He said, 'I am tired.'
He said that he was tired.
He says, 'I am tired.'
questions.explanation: Option B reports what was said without quotation marks, making it indirect speech.

questions.question: Convert to indirect speech: 'I watched a movie last night,' said Simran.
options: Simran said that she had watched a movie the previous night.
Simran said that she watched a movie last night.
Simran said that she has watched a movie last night.
questions.explanation: The past simple 'watched' changes to past perfect 'had watched,' and 'last night' becomes 'the previous night' in indirect speech.

questions.question: What is the direct speech of: The librarian told us to keep quiet.
options: The librarian said, 'Keep quiet.'
The librarian said, 'You should keep quiet.'
Both A and B
questions.explanation: Both options could be correct as they reflect possible original statements.

questions.question: Choose the correct indirect speech: 'I am studying now,' said my sister.
options: My sister said that she was studying then.
My sister said that she is studying now.
My sister says that she was studying now.
questions.explanation: The present continuous 'am studying' changes to past continuous 'was studying,' and 'now' changes to 'then.'

questions.question: Identify the error: He said that he can play cricket.
options: 'can' should be 'could'
'play' should be 'played'
No error
questions.explanation: In indirect speech, 'can' should change to 'could' when the reporting verb is in the past.

questions.question: Convert to direct speech: The children said that they were happy.
options: The children said, 'We are happy.'
The children said, 'We were happy.'
The children said, 'We will be happy.'
questions.explanation: The past tense 'were happy' in indirect speech changes to present tense 'are happy' in direct speech.

questions.question: What is the indirect speech of: 'I have just finished my lunch,' said Arjun.
options: Arjun said that he has just finished his lunch.
Arjun said that he had just finished his lunch.
Arjun said that he finished his lunch.
questions.explanation: The present perfect 'have finished' changes to past perfect 'had finished' in indirect speech.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: In indirect speech, 'here' often changes to ___.
options: there
this place
that
questions.explanation: Place words like 'here' change to 'there' in indirect speech to adjust the reference.
